conclusion: Use principles of magnetic induction and frictional force; magnetic induction intensity B = 3 + 2t T; resistance of wire frame is 4 Ω; side length of square is 0.2 m.
Calculate magnetic flux through square wire frame using formula: φ = B × Area.
Calculate area of square: Area = 0.2 × 0.2 = 0.04 m².
Calculate magnetic flux φ at t = 2.5 s: φ = (3 + 2 × 2.5) × 0.04 = 0.28 Wb.
Determine magnetic force on wire frame using formula: F = B × I × L; I is current, L is length of wire; wire frame remains stationary, current I is constant.
Calculate current I using resistance R: I = V/R; resistance is 4 Ω.
Voltage V is calculated as: V = I × R = I × 4.
Calculate magnetic force F at t = 2.5 s: F = (3 + 2 × 2.5) × 0.04 × 4 = 0.28 N.
Determine frictional force; since wire frame remains stationary, frictional force F_f is equal to magnetic force F.
Since wire frame remains stationary, frictional force F_f is constant and equal to magnetic force F.
Calculate frictional force at t = 2.5 s: F_f = 0.28 N.
Since frictional force is constant, magnitude of frictional force at t = 2.5 s is 0.28 N.
Determine direction of frictional force; since wire frame remains stationary, frictional force acts in direction opposite to magnetic force.
Since magnetic force is directed towards the right, frictional force will be directed towards the left.
Direction of frictional force at t = 2.5 s is to the left.
